case_vignette: A 30-year-old healthy Hispanic woman presents with a slowly progressive facial deformity present since early childhood. She denies any new lesions during this time, any history of trauma to the area, and any family history of similar skin lesions. Examination reveals a bulging, deformed dermal mass with a “bag-of-worms” appearance involving the upper right quadrant of her face, with hypertrophy of the overlying skin and soft tissues. Neurofibromas and café-au-lait macules are not observed.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've had a slowly growing facial deformity that's been present since I was a little kid.
What is your current age?
I am 30 years old.
Is the facial deformity associated with any other symptoms like pain or changes in skin color?
No, I haven't noticed any new symptoms, pain, or changes in skin color.
Have you had any previous medical evaluations or treatments for this deformity?
I haven't mentioned any evaluations or treatments for the deformity.
Do you have any family members with similar or other types of deformities?
No, there's no family history of similar skin lesions.
Are there any other areas of your body that have been affected or is it confined to your face?
It's just confined to my face, specifically the upper right part.
Does the deformity seem to be superficial involving only the skin or does it also affect deeper tissues like bone or muscle?
The deformity is like a bulging mass involving the deeper layers beneath my skin and has caused thickening of the skin and soft tissues on top.
Has the deformity affected your breathing, vision, or ability to eat?
I haven't mentioned any issues with breathing, vision, or eating.
Does the facial deformity change in size or appearance over time or with certain activities?
It's been slowly progressive since early childhood but I haven't noticed any new changes recently or with certain activities.
Final Diagnosis: Congenital Hemifacial Hypertrophy

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient visits the clinic with a slowly growing facial deformity that has been present since childhood. The patient is 30 years old and has not noticed any new symptoms, pain, or changes in skin color. There is no mention of any evaluations or treatments for the deformity. The patient also denies any family history of similar skin lesions and reports that the deformity is confined to the upper right part of the face. The deformity is described as a bulging mass involving the deeper layers beneath the skin, causing thickening of the skin and soft tissues on top. The patient has not experienced any issues with breathing, vision, or eating. The deformity has been slowly progressive since early childhood, but the patient has not noticed any new changes recently or with certain activities.
